comments.body: Strictly speaking, I don't think we really need to deactivate. It isn't as if we are putting the environment back into the state we started with anyway (some of these may have been defined before activation).
@jakirkham - the one remaining thing to discuss.

> Strictly speaking, I don't think we really need to deactivate.

So, I'm thinking about this from a versatility perspective. If one wants to use this locally, to build something and then switch environments. We should really try to clean stuff up so they don't have a surprise error down the line.

> It isn't as if we are putting the environment back into the state we started with anyway (some of these may have been defined before activation).

Eek. 🐭 I hope not. Personally, I try to keep my environment super pristine. There are just way too many things environment variables affect. Besides, as an end user, I think it is much easier to solve this scenario, "Oh, apparently this isn't set. Let's set it.", than this one, "It does appear to be set. What is wrong with it?".

In the future, we certainly can discuss storing the pre-activation environment variables somewhere else and then reloading them during post-activation.

> We should really try to clean stuff up so they don't have a surprise error down the line.

But that is what forks do for us. We aren't changing the environment of the process that actually called `conda build recipe`, just the environment within the conda-build subprocess call. No?
You would be surprised the things I see people doing with the `gcc` package. A little safety didn't hurt anyone. 😉
I remain unconvinced, but it isn't worth worrying about 😉 .

So, one example is I have seen people install `gcc` and then `pip` install things. This can work sometimes. In other cases, it causes problems.

In the same way, I could see someone installing this with `conda`. I would rather we aim to have this behave in the least surprising way possible in that scenario than get complaints of weird bugs.
We can discuss more in the feedstock if you would like.
